semantic_title: Coding Guidelines for Atherosclerotic Coronary Artery Disease and Angina with Combination Codes
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 9. Diseases of the Circulatory System > b. Atherosclerotic Coronary Artery Disease and Angina

content.full_text: ICD-10-CM has combination codes for atherosclerotic heart disease with angina pectoris. The subcategories for these codes are I25.11, Atherosclerotic heart disease of native coronary artery with angina pectoris and I25.7, Atherosclerosis of coronary artery bypass graft(s) and coronary artery of transplanted heart with angina pectoris. When using one of these combination codes it is not necessary to use an additional code for angina pectoris. A causal relationship can be assumed in a patient with both atherosclerosis and angina pectoris, unless the documentation indicates the angina is due to something other than the atherosclerosis. If a patient with coronary artery disease is admitted due to an acute myocardial infarction (AMI), the AMI should be sequenced before the coronary artery disease. (Evidence: pg no: 52-53, L50-L57)
content.summary: Guidelines for using combination codes for atherosclerotic heart disease with angina and sequencing rules with AMI (Evidence: pg no: 52-53, L50-L57)
key_concepts: Combination codes for atherosclerotic heart disease with angina (Evidence: pg no: 52, L50-L52)
Subcategories I25.11 and I25.7 (Evidence: pg no: 52, L51-L52)
No additional angina code needed (Evidence: pg no: 53, L55-L56)
Assumed causal relationship (Evidence: pg no: 53, L56-L57)
AMI sequencing priority (Evidence: pg no: 53, L57)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Use combination codes I25.11 or I25.7 for atherosclerotic heart disease with angina (Evidence: pg no: 52, L51-L52)
detailed_rules.explanation: ICD-10-CM provides specific combination codes that include both atherosclerotic heart disease and angina pectoris in single codes (Evidence: pg no: 52, L50-L52)
common_applications: Native coronary artery disease with angina

detailed_rules.rule_text: Do not use additional angina code with combination codes (Evidence: pg no: 53, L55-L56)
detailed_rules.explanation: When using combination codes I25.11 or I25.7, it is not necessary to assign an additional code for angina pectoris (Evidence: pg no: 53, L55-L56)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Assume causal relationship unless documented otherwise (Evidence: pg no: 53, L56-L57)
detailed_rules.explanation: A causal relationship can be assumed between atherosclerosis and angina pectoris unless documentation indicates the angina is due to something other than atherosclerosis (Evidence: pg no: 53, L56-L57)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Sequence AMI before coronary artery disease when both present (Evidence: pg no: 53, L57)
detailed_rules.explanation: If a patient with coronary artery disease is admitted due to acute myocardial infarction, the AMI should be sequenced before the coronary artery disease (Evidence: pg no: 53, L57)

workflow_steps: Step 2: Determine if angina is present
Step 3: Check for causal relationship documentation
Step 6: Apply sequencing rules if AMI present

incorrect_coding.rationale: Would be incorrect double coding when combination code available
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Using separate codes for atherosclerosis and angina

warnings: Do not double code angina when using combination codes (Evidence: pg no: 53, L55-L56)
best_practices: Use combination codes when both conditions present (Evidence: pg no: 52, L50-L52)
Sequence AMI first when present with CAD (Evidence: pg no: 53, L57)
Assume causal relationship unless documented otherwise (Evidence: pg no: 53, L56-L57)
common_mistakes: Adding separate angina code with combination codes
tips: Check documentation for non-atherosclerotic angina causes (Evidence: pg no: 53, L56-L57)
